Name: Instruction of Hardjedef
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: Attributed to the royal prince Hardjedef, son of Khufu, this early ethical treatise offers moral instruction grounded in Maat. Though surviving only in Middle Kingdom copies, it reflects Old Kingdom ideals of truthfulness, restraint, and divine order.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Initiator, Self, Father Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Author: Hardjedef

Literary Themes Tags: Didactic / Ethical

Name: Instruction of Kagemni
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: An early court instruction attributed to the vizier Kagemni, this brief treatise praises the silent, humble man as the ideal servant of Maat. It emphasizes self-restraint, listening, and moral clarity as elite virtues.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Initiator, Self, Father Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Author: Kagemni
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly

Literary Themes Tags: Didactic / Ethical, Introspective

Name: Pyramid Texts
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A liturgical corpus inscribed on Old Kingdom royal tombs to guide the deceased king through the afterlife and secure his eternal divinity. The texts functioned as both resurrection spells and cosmic affirmations of pharaonic kingship.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Initiator, Wise Old Man, Hero, Mother Archetype, Father Archetype, Terrible Mother
Neumann Stages Tags: Death, Descent into the Underworld, Initiation, Rebirth, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Ego Transcendence, Coronation of the King

Name: Instruction of Ptahhotep
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: One of the oldest known wisdom texts, attributed to Vizier Ptahhotep of the 5th Dynasty. Framed as ethical instruction for elite youth, it promotes humility, justice, and social harmony rooted in Maat. More codified and structured than the earlier Instruction of Kagemni, it reflects the bureaucratic ideals of a civilization seeking moral continuity amid signs of political fragmentation.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Initiator, Self, Father Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community, Ego Transcendence
Author: Ptahhotep
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly
Literary Forms Tags: Manual / Instruction, Riddle / Aphorism, Parable / Fable
Literary Themes Tags: Didactic / Ethical, Introspective

Name: Surgical Papyrus (Edwin Smith collection)
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A surgical treatise based on older Old Kingdom knowledge presents 48 trauma cases in a rational, systematic format — offering diagnoses, prognoses, and treatments without magical incantation. With its detailed anatomical insight and triage-based logic, it stands as the oldest known medical document rooted in empirical observation and structured intervention.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Death, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Author: Imhotep
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly
Literary Forms Tags: Manual / Instruction, Glossary / Taxonomy, Analysis

Name: The Instruction of Merikare
Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Phenomenology (Experiential)
Short Description: The final advice of a dying Pharaoh to his heir, emphasizing ethical kingship, pragmatic mercy, and internal order in a world still scarred by collapse. It reflects a symbolic shift toward a more humanized and ethically grounded vision of rulership.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Initiator, Self, Father Archetype, Shadow
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community, Ego Transcendence

Literary Forms Tags: Manual / Instruction, Essay / Argument, Riddle / Aphorism
Literary Themes Tags: Didactic / Ethical, Political, Introspective

Name: Liturgy of Funerary Offerings (Abydos Ritual)
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Becoming (Process Ontology), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable)
Short Description: A ritual sequence of offerings and invocations performed at Abydos, the sacred city of Osiris. Designed to transform the deceased into an Osirian figure, it ensured eternal life through divine association. Unlike earlier funerary texts filled with danger and trial, this liturgy offers a more serene vision of death—grounded in ritual certainty. A further step in the democratization of sanctity.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Initiator, Self, Hero, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Shadow, Mother Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Death, Initiation, Magical Empowerment, Rebirth, Descent into the Underworld, Ego Transcendence, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Literary Forms Tags: Poetry, Liturgy, Myth, Fragment
Literary Themes Tags: Ritual / Devotional, Metaphysical, Cosmological, Mystical / Initiatory

Name: Book of Two Ways
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: An early illustrated underworld guide found in Middle Kingdom coffins, the Book of Two Ways maps two possible routes to the afterlife—by land and by water—framed as a perilous spiritual journey toward union with Osiris. Combining myth, cosmology, and ritual defense, it became a prototype for later funerary books.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Hero, Initiator, Wise Old Man, Shadow, Trickster
Neumann Stages Tags: Death, Descent into the Underworld, Initiation, Battle with the Dragon, Magical Empowerment, Rebirth, Ego Transcendence, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Prophecy of Neferti
Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation), Dialectics (Conflict), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: A politically motivated "prophetic" text set in the Old Kingdom but written in the early 12th Dynasty. The text foretells chaos and social inversion, only to herald the rise of Amenemhat I as a divinely ordained restorer of order — blending apocalyptic vision with royal legitimation.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Hero, Self
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality, Coronation of the King, Divine Intervention, Rebirth
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Royal, Subversive / Revolutionary
Literary Forms Tags: Poetry, Narrative, Essay / Argument, Fragment
Literary Themes Tags: Apocalyptic / Eschatological, Political, Prophetic / Revelation, Historical Reflection, Didactic / Ethical

Name: Teaching of King Amenemhat I
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Subversion (Negation), Genesis (Process Realism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Dialectics (Conflict)
Short Description: A posthumous instruction attributed to Amenemhat I, founder of Egypt’s 12th Dynasty. Speaking from beyond the grave, the king recounts his betrayal and warns his son to rule with caution and vigilance. Both political testament and royal wisdom, it blends ethical counsel with deep distrust—reflecting the anxieties of succession and power.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Wise Old Man, Initiator, Terrible Father, Self, Persona, Hero
Neumann Stages Tags: Death, Initiation, Isolation, Battle with the Dragon, Descent into the Underworld, Ego Collapse, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Hymn to the Nile
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Becoming (Process Ontology)
Short Description: A poetic hymn celebrating the Nile as the life-giving force of Egypt. The river is deified as both mystery and provider, sustaining crops, people, and kingship alike. By sacralizing the natural order, the text subtly reinforces the cosmic legitimacy of pharaonic rule.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Mother Archetype, Father Archetype, Self, Wise Old Man, Shadow
Neumann Stages Tags: Uroboric Stage, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Divine Intervention, Rebirth, Magical Empowerment, Initiation

Literary Forms Tags: Poetry, Liturgy, Myth

Name: Tale of the Shipwrecked Sailor
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology)
Short Description: A court official, preparing to meet Pharaoh, recounts the tale of a shipwrecked sailor who survives cosmic disaster and encounters a divine serpent on a mysterious island. Framed as a story within a story, the serpent—who blesses, tests, and vanishes—mirrors Pharaoh himself. The tale imparts lessons of humility, awe, and impermanence, reflecting Egypt’s deeper understanding that collapse and restoration are woven into the fabric of existence.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Wise Old Man, Self, Initiator
Neumann Stages Tags: Uroboric Stage, Isolation, Divine Intervention, Initiation, Rebirth, Return to the Community

Name: The Admonitions of Ipuwer
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A text mythologizing the breakdown of social, cosmic, and political order. Framed as a court sage’s lament, it captures the trauma of Egypt’s collapse into chaos, simultaneously mourning the death of maat and implicitly calling for a renewed divine kingship to restore balance.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Wise Old Man, Initiator, Terrible Father, Self, Persona

Name: Tale of Sinuhe
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A narrative that follows an Egyptian official who flees into exile after the king’s death and rises to prominence abroad, only to return in old age and be ritually reintegrated into Egyptian order. The tale reflects the tension between inner dislocation and the redemptive pull of Maat and kingship.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Shadow, Wise Old Man, Self
Neumann Stages Tags: Separation from World Parents, Isolation, Initiation, Return to the Community, Rebirth, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Coffin Texts
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: An evolving body of funerary spells written on non-royal coffins during the First Intermediate and Middle Kingdoms. Adapted from Pyramid Texts, they enabled elites to access the afterlife, reflect the rise of Osirian theology, and signal a symbolic shift from royal exclusivity to broader spiritual participation.

Name: Dialogue of a Man with His Ba
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Subversion (Negation), Becoming (Process Ontology)
Short Description: A despairing man debates with his ba (soul), wrestling with the meaning of life, death, and spiritual fatigue. Unresolved and deeply introspective, it is Egypt’s most profound philosophical lament—where inner crisis replaces ritual certainty, and the soul itself becomes both witness and adversary.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Self, Wise Old Man, Trickster, Persona, Initiator
Neumann Stages Tags: Isolation, Ego Collapse, Initiation, Death, Descent into the Underworld, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Loyalist Instruction
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: An instructional text cultivating political loyalty and moral conduct. The Loyalist Instruction trains elite officials to uphold order through unwavering obedience to the king, presenting devotion to the pharaoh as the highest form of virtue.

Name: Satire of the Trades (Teaching of Dua-Khety)
Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: An instructional satire in which the scribe Dua-Khety mockingly portrays all other professions as miserable and degrading, elevating the scribal path as the only dignified life—using humor to normalize bureaucratic privilege.

Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community

Name: The Eloquent Peasant
Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: A literary narrative in which a poor peasant uses eloquent speech to appeal for justice after being wronged by a landowner. Through nine formal orations, the text dramatizes the power of language to invoke maat, critiquing elite silence and affirming divine kingship as the ultimate arbiter of justice.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Hero, Wise Old Man, Shadow, Trickster

Name: Moscow Mathematical Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The papyrus contains 25 arithmetic and geometric problems, many of which are framed in practical, real-life contexts—including calculations of areas, volumes, and proportions relevant to architecture, storage, and distribution. Among its most notable achievements is the correct formula for the volume of a truncated pyramid (frustum)—a sophisticated geometric insight for its time. Other problems involve proportional allocations of bread or beer, indicating use in economic planning or education.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly
Literary Forms Tags: Analysis, Rulebook / Code

Name: Kahun Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The Papyrus contains 34 clinical cases dealing with women's health — from fertility and pregnancy diagnosis to contraception and reproductive disorders. It presents symptom-based diagnostics followed by treatments using herbs, oils, and fumigation, laid out in a proto-logical "if–then" structure. The text forms part of a broader corpus including mathematical and administrative documents. Other fragments relate to veterinary medicine and indicate an early systematization of bodily knowledge.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Death, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly
Literary Forms Tags: Manual / Instruction, Glossary / Taxonomy, Rulebook / Code, Fragment
Literary Themes Tags: Feminine

Name: Hymn to Osiris
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A priestly hymn venerating Osiris as the cosmic king who triumphs over chaos, ensuring the resurrection of order and civilization itself. Composed during Egypt’s recovery from political fragmentation, it weaves the death and rebirth of both Pharaoh and society into a sacred, eternal cycle.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Hero, Initiator, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Shadow

Name: Berlin Papyrus 6619
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The papyrus contains a set of mathematical problems, most notably a problem that amounts to solving a quadratic equation using verbal and geometric logic. The papyrus showcases an advanced understanding of relationships between unknown quantities, solved through area-based reasoning rather than symbolic algebra. It reflects a moment in Egyptian intellectual history where mathematics was not only practical but also capable of abstraction.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Death, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly

Name: Tales of Wonder (Westcar Papyrus)
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: A cycle of magical tales told at King Khufu’s court, culminating in a prophecy of the divine birth of the 5th Dynasty kings. Composed centuries later for a Middle Kingdom audience, it reflects the 12th Dynasty’s effort to legitimize its own rule by aligning with the solar theology.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Wise Old Man, Initiator, Trickster, Self

Name: Rhind Mathematical Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: An instructional manual in arithmetic, algebra, and geometry compiled around 1550 BCE by the scribe Ahmes, based on an earlier Middle Kingdom source from c. 1850 BCE; the Rhind Mathematical Papyrus presents practical problems used in taxation, surveying, and grain measurement, reflecting the empirical logic and bureaucratic sophistication of Egypt’s classical administrative era.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly

Name: Ebers Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A priestly-medical compendium from c. 1550 BCE, the Ebers Papyrus blends herbal remedies, magical spells, and empirical observations into a system of ritual healing. Mobilizing mathematics for dosage and diagnosis, it reflects the integration of sacred and practical knowledge in the service of restoring bodily and cosmic order.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Death, Magical Empowerment, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Stela of Kamose
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation), Becoming (Process Ontology)
Short Description: A monumental inscription from Kamose, king of Thebes, declaring sacred war against the foreign Hyksos rulers of northern Egypt. Framing military action as a cosmic duty to restore maat, the stela blends religious symbolism with martial defiance, rearming kingship as the avenger of sacred order.

Name: Book of Amduat
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: The text narrates the sun god Ra’s nightly journey through the underworld, paralleled by the deceased pharaoh’s own path to rebirth. It sacralizes the king’s role by integrating him into cosmic cycles, transforming his earthly conquest into divine renewal — a priestly affirmation of dynastic power.

Name: Litany of Re
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: The Litany of Re presents 75 divine forms of the sun god, transforming the king’s heroic identity into a vessel for sacred recitation. Rather than dramatizing conquest, it subdues the warrior impulse by absorbing it into a cyclical ritual of divine names and cosmic order.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Hero, Wise Old Man, Initiator, Father Archetype

Name: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A hymn exalts Amun as the hidden source of all life, the creator of gods and men, and the sustainer of maat, the cosmic principle of order. Praised as both transcendent and immanent, Amun is depicted as the unknowable One who animates all phenomena while remaining veiled. The hymn serves as a piece of political theology: it elevates the pharaoh’s authority as divinely sanctioned and, simultaneously the Amun priesthood of Thebes, aligning their temple with the architecture of the cosmos.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Father Archetype, Initiator
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality, Ego Transcendence, Coronation of the King, Initiation
Name.1: Hymn to Amun-Ra (or Great Hymn to Amun)

Name: Book of the Heavenly Cow
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Subversion (Negation), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A funerary myth describing humanity’s rebellion, divine punishment by Hathor, and Re’s retreat to the heavens. It explains the origin of suffering and death as consequences of human defiance. Composed after the Amarna Period, it restores traditional theology and cosmic hierarchy.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Terrible Mother, Father Archetype, Shadow, Initiator, Wise Old Man

Name: The Great Hymn to the Aten
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Becoming (Process Ontology), Phenomenology (Experiential)
Short Description: A religeous hymn composed under Pharaoh Akhenaten, reflecting a radical theological reordering of the cosmos through solar monotheism. It represents an internal symbolic war within Egypt’s priesthood, seeking to erase the traditional pantheon and re-center divine mediation solely through the Pharaoh.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Father Archetype, Initiator, Hero

Name: Book of Gates
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable)
Short Description: A funerary text mapping the Pharaoh's night journey through the underworld, structured around twelve gates guarded by divine powers. It presents death as an initiatory passage necessary for cosmic regeneration, transforming mortality into an organized myth of triumph through divine knowledge and allegiance.

Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation), Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A royal proclamation issued by the general-turned-Pharaoh Horemheb, deploying law to restore cosmic and political order after Egypt's collapse into chaos during the Amarna Period. It reasserts maat through a fusion of military authority and sacred kingship.

Name: Poem of Pentaur (Battle of Kadesh)
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A heroic narrative praising Ramesses II’s valor at the Battle of Kadesh against the Hittites. Though the battle ended in stalemate, the poem recasts it as a divine-backed solo victory by the king. Inscribed across temples, it glorifies warrior kingship and reaffirms the king’s sacred role as Egypt’s protector.

Name: Turin King List
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: The text is a fragmented yet uniquely comprehensive chronological record of Egyptian kings. The list presents a systematic, column-and-row format noting the names, reign lengths, and occasionally annotations of rulers from Egypt’s mythical past through the historical dynasties. Unlike more ideological king lists, it includes foreign rulers, short-lived kings, and even Hyksos rulers, indicating a clerical effort to preserve an objective dynastic archive.
Neumann Stages Tags: Uroboric Stage, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Book of the Earth
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Monism (Single Principle), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable)
Short Description: A funerary liturgy depicting the sun god’s descent and regeneration within the underworld. Unlike earlier mythological texts, it renders death as a metaphysical process—structured, segmented, and ritually governed. Its esoteric diagrams and divine logic reflect priestly attempts to cosmicize kingship during an age of symbolic rigidity.

Name: Victory Stela of Merneptah (Israel Stela)
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: A royal inscription celebrating military victories in Libya and Canaan. It famously declares “Israel is laid waste,” marking the earliest known mention of Israel in the historical record. Composed at a time of imperial contraction, the text asserts pharaonic strength and cosmic order through divine-backed conquest.

Name: Contendings of Horus and Seth
Metaphysical Tags: Subversion (Negation), Dialectics (Conflict), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: A mythological satire that dramatizes the struggle for divine kingship between Horus and his uncle Seth. Told as a divine courtroom comedy filled with absurd trials and grotesque contests. Composed for elite scribal circles, the text ironizes mythic authority while reaffirming Horus as the rightful heir through ritual parody, revealing signs of symbolic collapse within a civilization questioning its own cosmic order.

Name: Love Songs of the Chester-Beatty Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: A collection of lyric poems from the early Ramesside period expressing romantic and erotic longing. Alternating between male and female voices, the verses celebrate desire, beauty, and emotional intimacy with playful sensuality. Composed within elite scribal circles, they reflect a world where love could be stylized, shared, and performed.

Name: Tale of the Two Brothers
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Subversion (Negation), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: A mythic tale that follows two brothers, Anubis and Bata, through betrayal, exile, magical transformation, and divine justice. Bata endures false accusation and symbolic death before being reborn and rising to kingship. Blending folk motifs with cosmic themes, the story reflects scribal creativity and royal ideology through narrative. Just like the Love Songs, it marks the emergence of human-centered storytelling within elite literary culture.

Name: Book of Caverns
Metaphysical Tags: Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Becoming (Process Ontology), Subversion (Negation), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: A funerary text depicting the soul’s terrifying trial through infernal caverns, where the hope of resurrection is suspended until maat is fully reaffirmed through judgment and punishment. It dramatizes the pharaoh’s essential cosmic role in re-securing rebirth at the edge of annihilation, where final ego transcendence remains possible—but more elusive.

Name: Instruction of Amenemope
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable)
Short Description: A wisdom text presenting ethical guidance for righteous living in an unstable and unjust world. Framed as a father’s advice to his son, it emphasizes humility, patience, self-restraint, and trust in maat over ambition or retaliation. Composed during a period of political fragmentation and priestly bureaucratization, the text stands as a sincere attempt to preserve spiritual integrity amid civilizational decline, offering inner maat as a refuge when outer structures falter.

Name: Deir el-Medina Strike Papyrus
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: Records the first known labor strike in history, when royal tomb builders protested delays in their rations under Ramesses III. The workers staged walkouts, appealed to local officials, and demanded dignity and compensation. The document reflects late New Kingdom strain, as Egypt’s symbolic economy clashed with its material disintegration.

Name: Harem Conspiracy Papyrus (Turin Judicial Papyrus)
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation), Phenomenology (Experiential)
Short Description: Records the judicial proceedings following a failed plot to assassinate Ramesses III, orchestrated by royal wife Tiye and her faction. The trials expose high-level court intrigue, resulting in executions and the purging of elite conspirators. Though framed as legal documentation, the text reasserts pharaonic sanctity through bureaucratic violence.

Name: Calendars of Lucky and Unlucky Days
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation)
Short Description: The texts represents a key component of Egypt’s ritual timekeeping system, categorizing each day of the year as favorable or unfavorable, often accompanied by mythological explanations such as battles between gods, cosmic events, or anniversaries of sacred occurrences. The text functioned as both an archive of sacred memory and a predictive corpus, allowing priests to advise when specific actions—traveling, eating, performing rituals—should or should not be undertaken.

Name: Hymn to Thoth
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: A richly poetic hymn honoring Thoth, god of wisdom, writing, time, and cosmic balance. Recited within temple settings, the hymn praises Thoth as the tongue of Ra, the scribe of maat, and the regulator of lunar and ritual cycles. Beyond praise, it presents Thoth as a cosmic principle: the divine mind that transforms chaos into order through speech, categorization, and measurement—indirectly elevating the scribal class by sanctifying their intellectual labor and binding it to the divine machinery of the cosmos.

Name: Story of Wenamun
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Subversion (Negation), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Short Description: A late Egyptian tale chronicling the priest Wenamun’s humiliating diplomatic mission abroad, exposing the collapse of Egyptian prestige through irony and narrative misadventure. A rare travel narrative that blends realism with satire, reflecting the disenchanted tone of a waning empire.

Name: Maxims of Ani
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A Late New Kingdom Egyptian wisdom text offering pragmatic moral advice for personal survival and social navigation in a world where traditional structures of power and divine order were increasingly unstable. It marks the internalization of maat as personal virtue, rather than public, cosmic assurance.

Name: Book of the Dead
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A funerary anthology from c. 1550 BCE onward, the Book of the Dead offers spells and prayers to guide the dead through the afterlife and achieve immortality. Evolving from royal tomb texts, it marks the democratization of salvation in Egypt for all who could afford it.

Name: Shabaka Stone
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A monumental text commissioned by King Shabaka. According to its preface, it preserves an ancient and decaying papyrus containing sacred knowledge, now engraved in stone to restore divine truth. At its core lies the Memphite Theology, a strikingly metaphysical vision in which the creator god Ptah brings the cosmos into being not through mythic action, but through mind (heart) and speech (tongue) — establishing a cosmos rooted in thought and logos, making it one of the earliest known examples of metaphysical reasoning embedded in theology.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality, Coronation of the King, Divine Intervention

Name: Psamtik I Karnak foundation text
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A royal inscription from the 26th Dynasty of Egypt, composed in hieroglyphs and buried in the foundations of the Karnak temple. Commissioned by Pharaoh Psamtik I (r. 664–610 BCE), the text proclaims his role as restorer of unity and divine order following a period of foreign domination and temple neglect. It emphasizes his devotion to the god Amun, his rebuilding of sacred structures, and his alignment with Ma’at.

Name: Necho II’s Decree at Kusae
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A formal royal proclamation issued by Pharaoh Necho II of Egypt’s 26th Dynasty. Inscribed in hieroglyphs on stone and likely displayed at the temple of Osiris in Kusae, the decree grants protections and privileges to the local priesthood. It forbids interference with temple property and invokes divine judgment against any violators. The decree affirms the king’s role as a restorer of sacred order (Ma’at) and guardian of the gods’ domains.
